description.narrative: This project is one of the initiatives to boost peace in Darfur using Livelihoods as a crucial peace engine and a major connector, which aims at improving livelihood and local economic recovery.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

provider-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of vulnerable households supported with assets to start productive activities disaggregated by value chain commodity and gender. 1.2 Percentage increase in agricultural production per household disaggregated by gender. 1.3 Number of Voluntary Savings and Loan Associations that are functional disaggregated by % of women and men participating. 1.4 Percentage of targeted households whose livelihood assets have increased in 36 months from project inception by gender. 1.5 Percentage increase in household 1.6 Percentage of beneficiaries reporting decrease in humanitarian aid and increased reliance on own resources by gender;

comment.narrative:
1.1.1 initial activities started to provide productive asset support including Seeds, tools and financial support to 5000 members of Value chain associations. This work is currently on hold due to COVID-19. 1.1.2 Some 63 vulnerable women in 6 groups have been selected to receive goats as livelihoods support in Tura. 1.1.3 Some 30 women groups have received support on cereal trade. 1.1.4 One group of 20 women have received Cereal and Spices milling machines in Tura 1.1.5 Nine (9) producer associations established in Assalaya, Ed El Fursan and Gereida (3 per locality) on livestock keeping, groundnuts production, dairy production. Partial training of the groups has been done on processing and marketing techniques. 1.1.6 A number of 250 households have been supported with donkey carts and livestock in Assalaya and El Daien localities; 1.1.7 A number of 30 associations are being supported in the production, processing and marketing of groundnuts, sesame and livestock. 1.1.8 Some 130 members of women associations in North Darfur are being trained and assisted to start production soaps, hand sanitizers and face masks as an income generation activity whilst contributing to the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.
1.2 To be measured at the end of the production season in November/December 2020; 1.3 Updates will be provided by end of the year 1.4 This target will be measured at the end of the year. 1.5 To be measured during Annual Survey in December 2020. 1.6 To be measured during Annual Survey in December 2020. 1.7 Twelve key productive and community infrastructure projects are being implemented: * The rehabilitation of the Tura Health Centre has begun, and a solar system and refrigerator procured. * Rehabilitation of one water yard in Tura has been completed, and materials and items for rehabilitation of a second water yard through the government water corporation is completed. * Technical drawings for the rehabilitation of the Tura dam has been completed and procurement process is on-going; * Rehabilitation of Mellit dam has started and currently on-going at 60% completion in North Darfur. * Two (2) Warehouse/Collection Center rehabilitation is on-going in Dare Salam locality on-going, and one existing Warehouse being rehabilitated; * Construction of 2 Warehouses and provision furniture and equipment in Malm Alwidian and Kalemendo is on-going; * Construction of solar powered Livelihoods Hub equipped with furniture in Kalemendo is on-going; * Completed 70% of establishment of Water Yard in Goz-Bena and extension and redistribution to Dagag through water yard; 2.2 It is estimated that these 12 infrastructures would benefit over 20,000 households in access to water for humans, livestock and irrigation, training and other community activities and market access and reduce post-harvest losses. 2.3.1 Some 950 vulnerable beneficiaries (more than 55% Female) were employed in temporary labor-intensive scheme in the construction of the above infrastructure which increased their monthly incomes by 70% during the period. 2.3.2 Some other 200 people (63% female) were engaged on voluntary basis for the rehabilitation of the dam. 2.4 To be measured at the end of year through perception surveys. 2.5 To be measured at the end of year through perception surveys.
3.1.1 Six (6) Peace and Development Committees comprising 90 members (80 males and 10 females) have been established and trained on peace building and conflict mitigation / resolution skills in Gereida, Ed El Fursan and Assalaya. 3.1.2 To boost capacity of the PDCs, 30 community members (28 males and 2 females) in South Darfur were trained as ToTs. The ToTs cascaded training to 60 other people [40 males and 20 females) in Assalaya. 3.1.3 Six Farm Protection Committees (FPCs) have been formed in Ed El Fursan, Assalaya and Gereida and training of 30 participants (29 males and one (1) female) conducted for the former two locations. 3.1.4 One (1) conference on reconciliation and peaceful coexistence and acceptance among warring tribes of Kutum and Alwaha was conducted to amicably dissipate tensions and recurring conflict between sedentary farmers, nomads, IDPs and Returnees and encourage voluntary return. The 180 participants were drawn from the Truth, Justice and Reconciliation Commissions (TJRC), the Voluntary Return and Rehabilitation Commission (VRRRC), Native Administrations, IDPs and Returnees, women and youth, influential persons, the uniformed forces, development partners, UNAMID, Office of the State Governor, HAC and the warring parties. A peace agreement was signed among the key parties witnessed by the Wali of North Darfur. 3.2 To be reported at the end of the year after perfection surveys are conducted. Meanwhile, the establishment of 6 PDCs have already contributed to access to these mechanisms. 3.3 To be reported at the end of the year after perfection surveys are conducted; 3.4 Monitoring processes are on-going in the target localities. So far, only 3 cases have been reported by the new PDCs of which 100% have been resolved.
4.1 The project engaged the University of El Fasher Center for Peace and Development Studies to conduct the capacity assessment of key institutions related to durable solutions in the four states to identify potential hosts for land information data centers. 4.2 Activities yet to be organized. 4.3 Due to the COVID-19, training activities planned have not been implemented. However, UNDP is procuring a number of ICT equipment to support 4 key Government institution. Procurement process currently on-going. 4.4 UNDP led six (6) verification missions in North Darfur, 2 vitrification missions and one assessment mission in West Darfur. UNDP also participated in 7 verification missions in East Darfur led by UNHCR. In all the above, UNDP facilitated the participation of HAC and VRRC in all these missions through logistic and financial assistance.
5.1 During the reporting period, up to 80% of the project staff are in place. Remaining staff required to maintain full capacity are being recruited. 5.2 During the reporting period 2 key field monitoring activities were carried out. However, during March, access to project locations was precluded by restrictions on movement. 5.3 Project risk log is being updated regularly. The key new risk that threaten the project is the COVID-19 which is likely to cause significant delays in the implementation process. Contingency measures are being put in place to mitigate risks. 5.4 One Project Board meeting was organized in February 2020
N/A as the project has started its activities in November 2019.
N/A as the project has started its activities in November 2019.

Workplan is under formulation (Draft targets will be under): 1. Support economic recovery in Darfur through reviving productive capacities and market access for most vulnerable groups, . including women, youth and IDPs 2. Strengthen Livelihoods for Peace and Recovery in Darfur (L4P) to enhance the resilience of conflict-affected communities by improving livelihoods and economic recovery as key drivers of peace and social cohesion
N/A as the project has started its activities in November 2019.
